```{r, include=FALSE}

library(ggplot2)
library(tidyverse)
library(kableExtra)

``` 

```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
```

### Analysis of petal and sepal lengths using `iris` dataset 

<br>

First, we call the iris dataset.

```{r call_iris}

data("iris")

kable(head(iris, 10)) %>%
  kable_styling("striped", position = "left", font_size = 10)

```

<br>

### Including plots

<br>

Let's create a plot of petal and sepal lengths of the three flower species: "versicolor" and "virginica."

```{r, point}

ggplot(iris, aes(x = Petal.Length, y = Sepal.Length,
                  shape = Species, color = Species)) +
  geom_point(size = 2) +
  scale_shape_manual(values = c(16, 8, 6)) +     
  scale_color_manual(values = c("brown", "blue", "darkgreen")) +  # red and blue
  labs(
    x = "Petal length (cm)",
    y = "Sepal length (cm)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

```

<br>

We can also made a boxplot petal lengths between the three species.

```{r, boxplot}

library(ggplot2)

iris.sub <- subset(iris, Species %in% c("versicolor", "virginica"))
ggplot(iris, aes(x = Species, y = Petal.Length, fill = Species)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(
    title = "Petal Length of Versicolor vs Virginica vs Setosa",
    x = "Species",
    y = "Petal Length (cm)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()
```

<br>

### Including Figures

<br>

We can also embed images of the flower species from the dataset.


```{r}

knitr::include_graphics('iris.png')

```

<br>

Based on these plots and the image, we can rank the petal and sepal lengths of the three flower species from largest to smallest as follows:

- Iris Virginica
    - Iris Versicolor
        - Iris Setosa
